questions.text:
What abnormalities do you visualize in the patient's OCT image?

![](/content/media/case-retina1-q1.png)
questions.title: Question 1

answers.answerText: A. Loss of Foveal Contour and Epi-retinal Membrane

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/case-retina1-q1-ans.png)

The abnormalities on the OCT are:

1. Loss of foveal contour and epi-retinal membrane​
2. Well-defined intra-retinal cysts
3. Sub-retinal fluid

### The Diagnosis is Cystoid Macular Edema

![](/content/media/case-retina1-q1-ans.png)

OCT findings associated with CME include loss of foveal depression, diffuse retinal thickening, and intra-retinal fluid as defined by areas of low reflectivity (black) that is often seen in the outer plexiform layer.
​
A small hypo-reflective cavity is also seen underneath the neurosensory retina indicative of sub-retinal fluid.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
Which of the following is the most reasonable first-line therapy for the patient's diagnosis?

![](/content/media/case-retina1-q3.png)

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/case-retina1-q3.png)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) can be caused by numerous underlying conditions such as diabetic retinopathy, central/branch retinal vein occlusion, uveitis, age-related macular degeneration, and post-operative phenomenon.
​
Given the patient's recent history of cataract surgery, and the absence of diabetes in his past medical history, the cause of CME is likely post-operative. A combination of topical NSAIDS and corticosteroids are used in management of postoperative CME.

title: Case 1
description: 67M presenting with acute unilateral vision loss OD
patientPresentation: A 67-year-old male presents to an emergency eye clinic with decreased unilateral vision loss from 20/50 to 20/100 OD since last visit. He had cataract surgery one month prior in this right eye. His most recent HbA1C was 5.4%. The patient's OCT is shown below.
footer:
### Learning Objectives:

1. Identify OCT findings associated with CME.​
2. Recognize the first line therapy for post-operative CME.
